history.content:
Gonna offer a different answer. I'm a senior whose done several high profile internships and have created a mobile app as a side project that had almost half a million downloads and was featured by Apple. I'm graduating this semester and will be a SWE making well over 200k a year.

Just pick and do what you're interested in. If you're not sure, just try a bit of everything.

It seems like the person above me doesn't understand that most SWEs aren't just code monkeys. A large portion of time is spent in meetings, design/brainstorm sessions, and defining architecture and project requirements. He or she says that managers and AI/ML researchers are the ones making decisions but doesn't seem to understand that those two roles are pretty different. Managers are often SWEs first and then are promoted into leadership roles. In fact, imo doing AI/ML research could shoehorn you into those research only roles and not more general leadership roles. Also, from my experience, not every ML/AI engineer is automatically good at SWE. He or she seems to have a pretty inflated view of themselves.

If you're interested in SWE, I'd recommend 161, 162, 164, 168, 186 and fill in the rest with stuff you're interested in.

Me: a senior who has worked in industrial ML research and loves it(hated the 61 series and SWE in general)

IMO: SWE is the new factory labor of the 21st century. Every company needs people to code but the managers/business people and AI/ML researchers come up with the ideas for what to code and then the engineers have to do the tedious job of building it. Every AI/ML person can do SWE as when they do independent research you usually have to engineer your own solutions as opposed to passing them to the SWE team. But since they spent such time honing their theoretical skills they are now more worthwhile to the company as thinkers rather than builders so they have the luxury of spending most of their time thinking and doing simple coding using the tools that are designed by you but built by the SWE team(ie autograd tools). This is nice because walking outside or taking breaks becomes on the job if you are still thinking about your job, as compared to the SWE  who are seen as slacking for every second they aren’t coding or dealing with Jira bugs. In contrast to ML, people who do SWE likely won’t have the theoretical knowledge to be coming up with these novel ideas. Also in terms of money AI/ML industry pays atleast as well as SWE often better. If you regularly have ideas that you believe to be innovative I would suggest the ML path.

---

children.subject: I can't tell if the first answer is trolling or not...  There are a ton of interesting hard problems in systems/cloud computing/web dev/... SWEs don't just sit behind their computer and do routine things all day. Coming up with solid solutions requires creativity and critical thinking. When you go deep into any topic you'll encounter extremely difficult things that require innovative solutions - the problems AI/ML people solve are just different types of problems than the ones SWEs solve.

Thanks for the input @anons. 

Would it be possible if a professor possibly provide their opinion?

I don't think this is pretentious. Not sure if you were the first student answer as well, but I think this a way better expression of that viewpoint. For someone who really loves math and appreciates the elegance of ML then the AI/ML route might be for them.

Dude you just love math and you're looking at the wrong place if you're looking for math in SWE lol

"I often read online that software engineering companies do not care about elegant solutions like UC Berkeley does. In fact, I heard many people say that coming up with nicer, more efficient algorithms are waste of time, and that other people won't understand them anyways"
Sorry but this isn't accurate at all^

AI and ML are very interesting because they are fields which 1. require a lot of mathematics and 2. is a relatively new field, so people have a lot of room to explore. I am not trying to claim that I am a some sort of genius student. However, I believe I can shed light on this perspective. In my first year at Berkeley, I felt extremely out of place. Many concepts I were learning did not have enough mathematics for me to enjoy. More disheartening were the stories I heard about software development in industry. I often read online that software engineering companies do not care about elegant solutions like UC Berkeley does. In fact, I heard many people say that coming up with nicer, more efficient algorithms are waste of time, and that other people won't understand them anyways. I do understand the reasoning behind these statements, as they are very logical and do fit the needs of the company, but they were against my goals in CS. The reason why I chose CS was to explore the beauty of the field. I wanted to come up with ideas that were both mathematically elegant and simple. I wanted to work on solving pressing problems in the world with a mathematical/scientific viewpoint.

This changed when I started this semester, taking 189 and doing research in AI. Although freshman year, I felt not at home, and regretted choosing CS instead of math as my major, suddenly, I felt like I was right where I needed to be. Finishing problem sets where we used beautiful mathematical properties to actually gain real-world results was very enjoyable. In research, learning how algorithms that control robots are grounded in theoretical concepts (such as inference as control/inverse rl) was the most interesting thing I did in my life. I felt like my need to find beauty and simplicity in the complex world through mathematics was satisfied.

I am not claiming that AI/ML is the only field that is intellectually stimulating. In fact, I am sure that there are a lot of fields that also have extremely pressing problems just waiting to be solved in elegant ways. However, I've always felt like my strive for elegance and simplicity was divergent from the path of a software engineer. Software engineering is a great job--it is very well paid, and does require a lot of creativity. However, I just dislike how, in my experience, it is neither founded in as deep of mathematics, nor as elegant as ML. Hopefully this doesn't come across pretentious (I am not trying to be, and this is my genuine opinion). Just let me know if it is, or if there parts anyone want to discuss or disagree/agree on.

I am a researcher at BAIR and a math double major. I want to respond to the first answer: No. We are all factory labors before we actually spent years working on the most challenging frontier of the field and achieve something.  Maybe some people use django, java or sql or quadtrees, maybe you know how to import tensorflow or pytorch and write a BERT - It all doesn't matter, both are based on tons of mathematics and bounds but are all SWE if we did not go to tackle the greatest challenge of the world.
On a side note, how difficult is it to pivot into an AI/ML role after doing SWE (assuming no grad school, just a bachelors)?

history.content:
Why does it seem like the most competitive students here go into AI/ML versus SWE?

What happens to the people who end up taking 126/127/189? Do they generally go into industry or grad school? 

I ask this because I am a sophomore unsure of what I want to do in the future. I'm much better at math/theory classes than coding, so it seems like I should go down the AI/ML path. In terms of interest, I am interested in both relatively equally. However, I am unsure of why AI/ML would be "better", or more fulfilling than SWE if SWE makes so much money. 

If possible, could a professor provide their opinion on this?
history.subject: SWE VS AI/ML Competitive students
